Award.AwardTitle: EDU: Collaborative: Educating the Security Workforce through On-Demand Live Competitions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States is facing a cyber-security crisis. Recent studies predict a shortfall of 1.5M global information security jobs by 2020. The lack of qualified cyber-security workforce gives rise to high-profile security incidents. In addition, attacks against the nation's critical infrastructure can have devastating effect that go well beyond the financial losses that we are witnessing today. Example targets include aviation control software, the power grid, and even the networks themselves, with the advent of new and emerging network-centric technologies such as software-defined networks. Therefore, it is crucial to educate the next generation of cyber-security professionals. Cyber-security exercises, in which students analyze software to discover flaws and mitigate them, are an excellent instructional method to effectively improve the security skills of protection, detection, and response.

Security training requires that developers acquire both the skills necessary to find security vulnerabilities in software, as well as the skills to fix existing flawed software. The knowledge that comes from studying vulnerabilities and vulnerability patterns provides students with the hands-on expertise to complement theoretical security skills. Live cyber-security exercises are an excellent tool to teach and reinforce security concepts in students. However, live cyber-security competitions place a significant time and effort burden on the organizers, because as soon as an intentionally-vulnerable software is used in a competition it cannot be used again. Therefore, all the time and effort spent creating the intentionally-vulnerable software is used on a single competition. In addition, running a live cyber-security competition requires technical skills (e.g., networking and server administration) that may be outside the expertise of educators. This project allows any educator or student, regardless of their technical skills, to host their own security competition. In addition, the participants will be able to create the intentionally-vulnerable software, which stimulates creativity and constructive behavior. Finally, this project will develop a repository of intentionally-vulnerable software, which allows educators to select sample vulnerable software from different vulnerability classes, furthering the educational goals of the instructor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States is facing a cyber-security crisis.  The lack of qualified cybersecurity workforce gives rise to a number of high-profile security incidents. Therefore, it is crucial to educate the next generation of cybersecurity professionals. Live cybersecurity exercises, in which participants analyze software to discover flaws, are an excellent instructional method to effectively improve the security protection, detection, and response skills of students.Unfortunately, these competitions are very complex to design, implement, and manage, as the associated infrastructure requires many interconnected components (team hosts, scoring components, game databases, scoreboards) with very stringent security requirements.Because of this complexity, live cybersecurity exercises are seldom used in educational settings.
This research effort created a series of tools and services (a CTF framework) that allows educators to easily deploy and manage live cybersecurity competitions.The developed framework was built on the lessons learned by running the world's largest educational cyber-security competition for 12 years (http://ictf.cs.ucsb.edu). The PIs recognized three important trends: (1) the amount of learning in creating the intentionally-vulnerable software is immense, (2) live one-off security competitions create technical and logistical burdens, and (3) educators often do not have readily available samples of vulnerable software.

Therefore, this research created a new CTF framework that supports the easy creation of live cybersecurity exercise.The framework leverages a number of open-source tools (such as Packer.io, Vagrant, and Terraform) to hide the complexity of instantiating and configuring a cybersecurity competition.In addition, the proposed system allows educators to create all the necessary components in the cloud, making it possible to run competitions of any size without the need for pre-existing computing infrastructure.The framework also includes a number of services that can be used to create test images.
The new CTF framework has been used to run two large-scale competition in 2017 and 2018, with more than 500+ teams participating world-wide.In addition, the framework has been used in several graduate classes as an educational and training tool.
The main impact of this research is democratizing access to security competitions, allowing educators to host their own competitions, with little-to-no technical expertise necessary. As part of the outreach efforts associated with this proposal, students of programs outside computer science, as well as high school students, have been educated on the security issues associated with the use of the Internet. 
The PIs have released the framework, the service targets, and the on-demand competition to the community. In addition, the PIs have published their novel ideas in peer-reviewed papers and have distributed the data associated with the two large-scale competitions that leveraged the framework.
